Even the old timers admit the two big snows of 1958 are the heaviest in fifty years. The first occurs February 15 & 16; the second the week of March 16. There are widespread traffic tie ups and considerable damage. Many families are without heat for three to four days when electricity fails. Here we see Cindy atop some of the drifts, a week after the first snowfall, near Manheim, which has been isolated for three days.

blocks.text: The "chemise" and the "bag", products of the "Roaring Twenties", come back into style in 1957 - 1958. Cindy dances a lively Charleston in a "chemise" to demonstrate the revival of both the dress and the dance. Published in the "Lancaster New Era" (Newspaper photograph).

blocks.text: February 15-20, 1958; Gordon and Walter Mcclair represent Educators Mutual Life Insurance Co. at a meeting of the Health Insurance Institute in Chicago. Although they miss the big snow storm at home, they encounter very bad driving conditions en route.
A room at The Drake in Chicago. It's ten degrees below zero outside.
Return trip somewhere along the Ohio Turnpike.
Snow falling; snow weather; the road ahead is blocked by snow; but the car gets through.

blocks.text: March 16 – 23, 1958; Gordon and Walter McClair visit South Carolina and Georgia for Educators Mutual Life Insurance Company (see map).
WASHINGTON HOTEL
BUILT 1744 IN THE REIGN OF KING GEORGE III.
Down the Eastern Shore: at Princess Anne, Md., the Washington Hotel, in operation since 1744.
Old Eastville, Va., boasts an inn built in 1780; a little courthouse, dating from 1632 with the oldest continuous court records in this country; and a debtors prison built in 1644.

blocks.text: Another motel, which has been closed all winter, is being covered by the blowing sands.
First night at Cavallieri Motor Court on Nags Head Beach, one of the very few accommodations available in March.

The Wright Memorial near Kitty Hawk,
North Carolina commemorates the
first airplane flight, achieved by
the Wright brothers in 1903. The
boulder marks the spot where the
plane took off.

Proceeding down the Outer Banks, the National Seashore Recreation Area, soon to become a part of the Federal park system, preserves 70 miles of unspoiled beachland...one of the few remaining stretches of undeveloped seashore in the East. The three islands - Bodie, Hatteras and Ocracoke are known as the "Graveyard of Ships".

blocks.text: The sands of Hatteras continue just under water for as much as twelve miles out into the Atlantic. This is the dread barrier all ships must avoid or suffer disaster. There is no accurate record of the number of ships which have been wrecked off Hatteras, but they run into the hundreds. Examples are shown above.

New fallen snow as we cross Soco Gap.

A side trip to Stokesdale and Summerfield, N. C., the region where Gordon's father was born and raised. Neither town shows much change in forty years. The house above (right) is where Gordon spent two months when he was eight years of age.

John Brown's fort has been rebuilt on the campus of Storer College for Negroes.

blocks.text: A trip with the Stricklers and Adees to Wynnewood, Pa. to attend a dinner party by Walter Reisner and Mabel Reisner.
Outdoor suppers are popular: (top) with John and Polly Rohrer; (center) with Dotty Wood; (bottom) with Dick and Charlotte Andes.

(Left) Kay Tucker arrives from Winston-Salem,
N. C. to be Cindy's guest for two weeks.
The girls met the year before for the first time.
They are first cousins, once removed.

blocks.text: Mid-July, 1958 - Gordon and Kitty spend a week end with Bob and Dotty Hummel at their new home in Florham Park, N. J. Saturday night visit to New York City where Bob gets a summons for running through a red light. On the way home, Gordon also gets a summons for going too fast through the (already asleep) town of Mt. Aetna, Pa.
Supper in our back yard with Jack and Jane Herr, Dick and Charlotte Andes. (Above, left) At John and Lucille Groenendaals' home with Clarence and Louisa Pontz.
Kathy and Cindy munch hamburgers, while Kitty lines up for chow at the Walter McClouds' in East Petersburg.

blocks.text: October 12, 1958 - On Cindy's 17th birthday, a late season visit to the ocean at Rehoboth and Dewey Beaches, Delaware. Nancy is unable to go along, so Sally Northup, friend of Kathy's, accompanies us. The girls go in the water, but Gordon and Kitty are content to read and relax on the sand.

blocks.text: The year 1958 is saddened by the deaths of Gordon's uncle, Thomas L. Evans, on October 21, and of Kitty's mother on November 14. Their loss will be felt deeply by all of us, for they were a large part of our lives.
It's a good way to earn extra spending money; Cindy finds as she rakes and burns leaves from our back yard.

blocks.text: May 20 – 23, 1959 - Gordon and Ron Fisher drive to Charleston, West Virginia to conduct a life training course for Educators Mutual Life Insurance Co. Total trip - 969 miles.
Harpers Ferry, W. Va., scene of John Brown's raid just prior to the Civil War, has become a National Monument with extensive restoration of buildings.
View from the top of the hill at Harpers Ferry...and John Brown's rebuilt fort on the campus of Storer College (Negro).

We re-enter West Virginia on the mountain road west from Strasburg, Va.
roadwest frrroom Strararaaburg, Vaa.
A hamlet in West Virginia with the unusual name of Bulltown.

Meeting in the Daniel Boone Hotel in Charleston, Ron Fisher and Ed Haught review some of the problems of life underwriting. Agents from West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee attended.

End - trip to Charleston, W. Va.

blocks.text: June 14, 1959 - Cindy and Pete Pringle at Rehoboth Beach, Delaware... strong winds... blowing sand... too cold for swimming.
Nancy and Leonard Witkonis ready for a big Franklin & Marshall College week end.

Educators Mutual Life holds its annual sales meeting at The Greenbriar, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va....with wives in attendance for the first time. Shown above: Herman Hoskins, Ed Guenther, Laurence Strickler.
The old Strasburg R. R. Revived. American Business Club has a family picnic on the trip to Leaman Place.

blocks.text: September 2, 1959 - The Landreaths purchase a second family car...a French made Renault Dauphine with sun roof...promptly nicknamed "Little Toot" in appreciation of the dual toned horn.

September 13, 1959 - Gordon and Kitty drive Cindy to Penn State where she is enrolled as a first year student. Her dormitory is Lyons Hall. Homesick?...not just yet. We seem to take enough baggage and paraphernalia along to keep two students well fitted.

blocks.text: Roommate Judy Homer & Cindy with exhibit of Oriental art.
The stands are well filled.

October 17-18, 1959 - Gordon, Kitty, Nancy, Kathy and Louise visit Cindy at Penn State for Homecoming Week-end. We see Penn State's undefeated football team win over Boston U. by score of 21-12. Nancy and Kathy stay the night with Cindy in the dorm; Gordon, Kitty and Louise drive 40 mi. to a motel neat Mt. Union, so great is the demand for accommodations.
Kitty relaxes in one of State's lounges for parents & guests.

blocks.text: The Claude Smith family and Pete Pringle have a holiday dinner at the Landreths.
While the children play games, Betty and Kitty peruse a photograph album.
Kitty wears a new hand knit sweater from Ireland.
Cindy and Pete ready to attend a formal dance at Lancaster Country Club.
Cindy declares: "It's good to be home again for a few weeks."
